issue.title: What is the stored pointer value of an empty weak_ptr?

blockquote.p:
1 Effects: Constructs an empty weak_ptr object.
2 Ensures: use_count() == 0.

3 Remarks: The second and third constructors shall not participate in overload resolution unless Y* is compatible with T*.
4 Effects: If r is empty, constructs an empty weak_ptr object; otherwise, constructs a weak_ptr object that shares ownership with r and stores a copy of the pointer stored in r.
5 Ensures: use_count() == r.use_count().

discussion.p: Note that neither specifies the value of the stored pointer when the resulting weak_ptr is empty. This didn't matter — the stored pointer value was unobservable for an empty weak_ptr — until we added atomic<weak_ptr>. /15 says:

blockquote.p: Remarks: Two weak_ptr objects are equivalent if they store the same pointer value and either share ownership, or both are empty. The weak form may fail spuriously. See .

discussion.p: Two empty weak_ptr objects that store different pointer values are not equivalent. We could correct this by changing /15 to "Two weak_ptr objects are equivalent if they are both empty, or if they share ownership and store the same pointer value." In practice, an implementation of atomic<weak_ptr> will CAS on both the ownership (control block pointer) and stored pointer value, so it seems cleaner to pin down the stored pointer value of an empty weak_ptr.

resolution.p: This wording is relative to N4800.

li.p: Modify as indicated (note the drive-by edit to cleanup the occurrences of "constructs an object of class foo"):

blockquote.p:
-1- Effects: Constructs an empty weak_ptr object, that stores a null pointer value.
-2- Ensures: use_count() == 0.

-3- Remarks: The second and third constructors shall not participate in overload resolution unless Y* is compatible with T*.
-4- Effects: If r is empty, constructs an empty weak_ptr object that stores a null pointer value; otherwise, constructs a weak_ptr object that shares ownership with r and stores a copy of the pointer stored in r.
-5- Ensures: use_count() == r.use_count().
